Podcast #273: How to Get a Job Promotion This Year - https://t.co/xHYvj1w0AA

We've entered the distribution era.

Products? Easy to build.
Content? Easy to create.
Getting attention? Nearly impossible.

The bottleneck has shifted.

Your podcast might be great. Your product might solve real problems. Your content might be valuable.

But if your packaging doesn't stop the scroll, none of it matters.

Thumbnails, titles, landing pages, visual hooks: this is where battles are won now.

Good content behind bad packaging = invisible.
Average content behind great packaging = millions of views.

The skill that matters most in 2025 isn't creation.

It's getting people to click in the first place.

quotedTweet.text:
If you make a podcast on YouTube, and you're not getting views/subs...

The reason why is that the perceived time risk is outweighing the value signal from the packaging.

When someone sees your video packaging come up on their feed, they glance down and see 45+ mins for the video.

To them, this is a high risk "investment" of time.

For them to click consistently, they need to be sure there will be value (entertainment/educational) on the other side

The shorter the video, the less perceived risk.

This is why it's so much harder to grow a video podcast channel than a normal YouTube channel.

It's not that the podcast videos are that much worse, it's that the perceived risk is that much greater.

So how do you solve for this?

To get them to click consistently you need to:

1. Tighten the desire loop promise in the title/thumbnail combo such that it speaks directly to your ideal viewer avatar (decide who it's for and then package it accordingly)

2. The imagery on the thumbnail needs to be of stuff they recognize and/or connect perfectly to the title promise

Title + thumbnail needs to signal high confidence of value on the other side of the click.

If you're not well known on YouTube, then putting your face on the thumbnail is not only not helping, but it can potentially be a counter signal (e.g., stranger danger type subconscious response).

I built a whole playbook specifically for YouTube podcast growth that breaks down how to solve for these things.

Let me know if you want.
